  1. On the Market
  2. Mortgage Calculator
  3. Living In
  4. The High End
  5. What You Get

Highlights

  1. The Hunt

    He Had $300,000 to Spend on the Hudson River Waterfront. Which of These Homes Would You Choose?

    After failing to find a suitable place in Manhattan, a first-time buyer crossed the river, so he could at least get a nice view of the city. Here’s what he found.

    16m agoBy Joyce Cohen

  2. On the Market

    Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey

    This week’s properties are six-bedroom houses in Babylon, N.Y., and Edison, N.J.

    2h agoBy Jill P. Capuzzo and Claudia Gryvatz Copquin

    1. Calculator

      Manhattan Lease Signings Are Booming. Is It Enough for a Recovery?

      Looking back through a year of lease-signing data reveals the beginning of something. But what?

      2h agoBy Michael Kolomatsky

    2. On the Market

      Homes for Sale in Brooklyn, Manhattan and Staten Island

      This week’s properties are in Park Slope, the East Village and Park Slope.

      2h agoBy Sydney Franklin

  1. Lizzie Borden’s Notoriety Is This Home’s Selling Point

    The house where her father and stepmother were brutally killed with a hatchet draws thousands of visitors a year. Now it’s for sale.

    6h agoBy Concepción de León

  2. International real estate

    House Hunting in Gibraltar: A Corner Townhouse on Main Street for $1.9 Million

    After getting caught in Brexit limbo, this sliver off the southern coast of Spain is ready to welcome more Europeans in search of something new.

    1d agoBy Roxana Popescu

  3. What You Get

    $350,000 Homes in Alabama, New Hampshire and Illinois

    A Craftsman cottage in Montgomery, a converted church in Keene and a Greek Revival house in Quincy.

    1d agoBy Julie Lasky

  4. Living in

    Colonia, N.J.: A ‘Nice’ Alternative to the City

    Good schools and reasonably priced homes have made this Woodbridge Township community popular with New York City buyers during the pandemic.

    1d agoBy Jill P. Capuzzo

  5. Guide

    How to Create a Serene Home

    Home should be relaxing, calming, an oasis. We’ll help you get there.

    November 18, 2020By Tim McKeough

  1. Sheltering

    When Evictions Loom, Pets Are Also at Risk

    Adoptions set a record in the U.S. early in the pandemic, but now millions of animals could be in danger of being abandoned or returned to shelters.

    2d agoBy Debra Kamin

  2. What I Love

    Isiah Whitlock Jr., on Leaving Chelsea for Gramercy Park

    The actor, known for starring roles on shows like “Your Honor” and “The Wire,” has a new apartment — with a key to the park.

    2d agoBy Joanne Kaufman

  3. renters

    Making a Home of Her Own in Brooklyn

    After several years of hunting, a domestic violence survivor and her daughter finally find a home, in East New York.

    January 18, 2021By Kim Velsey

  4. What you Get

    $1.2 Million Homes in California

    A modern townhouse in Laguna Beach, a two-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a 1932 stone cottage in Burbank.

    2d agoBy Angela Serratore

  5. Ask Real Estate

    The Noise Upstairs Is Unbearable. How Do I Stop It?

    You have the right to live in peace — easier said than done in an apartment building where everyone’s cooped up for the winter.

    January 16, 2021By Ronda Kaysen

Advertisement

Continue reading the main story

Ask Real Estate

More in Ask Real Estate ›

  1. Options for Struggling Landlords Whose Tenants Can’t Pay the Rent

    Critical eviction moratoriums don’t offer much relief for mom-and-pop landlords who still have to pay to keep their buildings operating.

    January 9, 2021By Ronda Kaysen

  2. My Packages Keep Getting Stolen. What Can I Do?

    A 2019 analysis found that 90,000 packages are lost or stolen every day in New York. And it’s only getting worse during the pandemic.

    January 2, 2021By Ronda Kaysen

  3. Is It Tacky to Give Holiday Tips Digitally?

    And now that we have Venmo, PayPal and other money-transfer services, are cash tips a thing of the past?

    December 19, 2020By Ronda Kaysen

  4. My Neighbor Won’t Shovel the Snow. How Do I Make Him?

    Shoveling snow is difficult work, and many people have obstacles that make it even harder. But it still has to get done.

    December 22, 2020By Ronda Kaysen

  5. How Much Do I Tip the Building Staff During the Covid Holidays?

    If ever there were a year to open your wallet wide, this is the one. But for New Yorkers who aren’t able to give this year, there are alternatives to cash.

    December 14, 2020By Ronda Kaysen

Living In

More in Living In ›

  1. Larchmont, N.Y.: An Affluent Suburb on Long Island Sound

    With a walkable downtown, spacious homes and proximity to Manhattan, this Westchester village has seen an influx of city buyers during the pandemic.

    January 15, 2021By Janine Clements

  2. Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.: An Inclusive Community on the River

    Many of the residents in this Westchester County village are city transplants, drawn by the creative, environmentally conscious vibe.

    January 7, 2021By Susan Hodara

  3. Wood-Ridge, N.J.: Not Too Close to the City, or Too Far Away

    This unpretentious suburb in Bergen County offers residents comfortable proximity to Manhattan and reasonably priced homes (some with skyline views).

    December 30, 2020By Jay Levin

  4. The Lower East Side: Where Historic Tenements Meet Glassy Towers

    In recent years, the country’s ‘most famous immigrant neighborhood’ has welcomed new high-end development. But it still has an old-school vibe.

    December 24, 2020By Aileen Jacobson

    Jan. 21, 2021

  3. A Home With Views of the ‘Rock’

    This three-story corner building on a bustling corner in the heart of Gibraltar is on the market with an asking price of $1.9 million.

    Jan. 20, 2021

  4. What You Get for $350,000

    A Craftsman cottage in Montgomery, Ala.; a converted church in Keene, N.H.; and a Greek Revival house in Quincy, Ill.

    Jan. 20, 2021

  5. Living In ... Colonia, N.J.

    Good schools and reasonably priced homes have made this Woodbridge Township community popular with New York City buyers during the pandemic.

    Jan. 20, 2021

  6. Square Feet

    Struggling Local Governments May Get Help From the Private Sector

    As their fiscal woes become worse, some government officials are looking more closely at public-private partnerships as a way to jump-start their economies.

    By Miranda S. Spivack

    Jan. 19, 2021

  7. Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions

    Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.

    By Isabella Paoletto

    Jan. 19, 2021

  8. Isiah Whitlock Jr.: ‘You’ve Got to Live in a Place You Love’

    The actor, known for starring roles on shows like “Your Honor” and “The Wire,” has a new apartment, with a key to Gramercy Park.

    Jan. 19, 2021

  9. What You Get for $1.2 Million in California

    A modern townhouse in Laguna Beach, a two-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a 1932 stone cottage in Burbank.

    Jan. 18, 2021

  10. What’s selling now

    Homes That Sold for Around $750,000

    Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.

    By C. J. Hughes

    Jan. 17, 2021
